intro: Lactuca sativa var. capitata, commonly known as romaine lettuce, is a cultivar of lettuce characterized by its crisp, dark green leaves and a slightly bitter taste. It is a member of the Asteraceae family and is native to Europe and western Asia. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a rosette of elongated, upright leaves. Romaine lettuce is prized for its nutritional value, containing high levels of vitamins A and K, and is widely used in salads and sandwiches. Its botanical features make it distinct from other lettuce varieties, such as iceberg or butterhead.
